title: My ex-boyfriend began spending & opening credit under my name without persmission. Help
question: I originally added him to some credit cards since we lived together and had been together over 7 years but never authorized to shop away and spend as he pleased. He then began opening up other cards without my knowledge and using them ruining my credit. We broke up over a year ago and he said he would pay all the cards as he listed in email but stopped paying. Now my accounts are all in collections and he will not return my calls or pay what he charged up. Any advice?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit repair,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Fraud,Criminal charges for identity theft,Police interrogation,Credit card fraud,Consumer protection,Small claims court
answers:
My legal guide on Avvo regarding Identity Theft walks you through all of the steps to protect yourself and to determine all of the accounts the scoundrel has opened illegally. It will also help you clean up your credit reports of the false accounts. If you read and follow the guide, you will greatly reduce the amount of time and stress that other victims experience.

Robert Stempler
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com

Report the ID theft ASAP, and put a fraud alert of your accounts so he can't open up any more accounts in your name.

Sue him for the debts he racked up, either in Small Claims, if it's less than $7,500, or in Superior Court if it's more.

Order your free credit report at www.annualcreditreport.com, and then address the fraud and errors using the FTC site's resources.

Start by making a complaint to law enforcement authorities. Be prepared to cooperate fully in any police investigation and to provide all documents as requested. Your failure to do that over the past year (if you haven't) may strengthen the credibility of an assertion by him that the use was authorized.

Take the initiative to contact the credit card companies. Don't expect to be believed, but put them on notice of the circumstances and ask where you can send to them copies of the police report.

You don't state the amount that is at issue, but you can handle the civil aspect of this in small claims court if it is within that court's jurisdictional limits, or you can talk with an attorney about bringing a civil lawsuit. Hang on to that email and all records of payment towards the obligations by him -- those may operate as admissions and they may be important evidence.

Even if you take these steps, you need to be emotionally prepared for the fact that it will be a long and difficult process to repair your credit.
